questions.question: What is blood pressure?
What is the SI unit of blood pressure?
questions.explanation: The SI unit of blood pressure is Pascal (Pa). It is conventionally expressed in mm of Hg.Note: 1 mmHg = 133 Pa.

questions.question: What is mean arterial pressure?
questions.explanation: Mean arterial pressure is diastolic + 1/3rd pulse pressure.The mean pressure is the average pressure throughout the cardiac cycle. It is not equal to theaverage of systolic and diastolic pressure because, at normal heart rates, a greater fraction of thecardiac cycle is spent in diastole than in systole. The mean arterial pressure is thereforedetermined by about 60 percent by the diastolic pressure and 40 percent by the systolic pressure.Mean BP= DBP + 1/3 Pulse pressure= DBP +1/3(SBP- DBP)= (3DBP+SBP- DBP)/3= 2/3 DBP + 1/3 SBP

questions.question: Korotkoffs sounds are due to

options.A: Increased laminar flow on application of
options.B: Closure of aortic valve in diastole
options.C: Arterial turbulence on occlusion of vesselpressure537
options.D: Normal sound that exist even without application of cuff

questions.explanation: Korotkoffs sounds are due to arterial turbulence on occlusion of the vessel.545The streamline flow in the unconstricted artery is silent. But when the artery is narrowed, thevelocity of flow through the constriction exceeds the critical velocity and turbulent flow results.Turbulent flow in the partly occluded brachial artery sets up the vibrations (oscillations) of thevessel wall which are heard through the stethoscope and are known as Korotkoffs sounds.

questions.question: When measuring blood pressure, which of the following is unlikely to show a spuriously highBP?
questions.explanation: The auscultatory gap may give a falsely low recording of systolic BP and overestimation ofdiastolic blood pressure not spuriously high BP.In older patients with wide pulse pressure and in some hypertensive patients, the Korotkoffsounds may become inaudible between SBP and DBP, and reappear as cuff deflation continues,this is known as auscultatory gap.Small cuff size, obesity, and thick calcified arteries can give rise to falsely high BP as in theseconditions, vessels are difficult to compress and higher cuff pressure is required to compressthem.

questions.question: The systolic pressure in the right ventricle is
questions.explanation: The systolic pressure in the right ventricle is about 25 mmHg.

questions.question: During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by:
questions.explanation: During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by the elastic recoil of the aorta. There is stretching of the aorta and arteries during systole due to the ejection of blood from the ventricle. During diastole, the previously stretched aorta and arteries recoil. The volume of blood that is displaced by the recoil furnishes continuous capillary flow throughout diastole.

questions.question: The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by
questions.explanation: The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by arterial wall expansion.Arterial Pulse•The blood forced into the aorta during systole not only moves the blood in the vessels forwardbut also sets up a pressure wave that travels along the arteries. The pressure wave expands thearterial walls as it travels and the expansion is palpable as the pulse.•The two major factors that influence arterial pulse are- stroke volume of the heart anddistensibility (compliance) of the vessels.546

questions.question: Carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to
questions.explanation: The carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to pulse pressure. They fire more rapidly to aconstantly changing pressure than a stationary one.Baroreceptors••●•Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vesselsTypes based on locationCarotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)• Afferents• Carotid sinus - a branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) - the carotid sinus nerve (sinusnerve of Hering)• Aortic arch receptor• Center for Reflex-a branch of the Vagus nerve (X CN) - aortic depressor nerve• Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius)• Efferents•Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature• Most sensitive to pulsatile pressure: They work to maintain BP in the range of mean BP, but it isthe changes in the pressure they are the most sensitive to.• The threshold for excitation: 50 mmHg• Maximal activity: 180 mmHg•Responses when one carotid sinus is isolated and perfused and the other baroreceptors aredenervated• Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg:no response•⚫ 70-110mm Hg: the linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BPand HR•>150mm Hg: no further increase in response to the degree of inhibition of the sympatheticnerve is maximal.

questions.question: Baroreceptor stimulation would result in

options.C: Decreased sympathetic discharge to the heart

questions.explanation:
Baroreceptor stimulation would result in decreased sympathetic discharge to the heart. The baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. Thus leading to: 
     • Vasodilation and venodilation
     • Hypotension
     • Bradycardia
     • Decrease in cardiac output

questions.question: The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is
questions.explanation: The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 180 mmHg (arterialpressure here and not MAP).The blood pressure range to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 70- 150 mmHg of meanarterial pressure.

questions.question: Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of:
questions.explanation: Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of Rostral ventrolateral medulla.The baroreceptors are stimulated by distension of the structures in which they are located. Theirafferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves to the medulla. These fibers releaseglutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius (NTS). These NTS neuronsthen excite neurons in the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). These CVLM neurons release theinhibitory neurotransmitter y-aminobutyric acid (GABA) into the RVLM to reduce the firing rateof these. Thus, reducing the sympathetic outflow.Neural pathway of baroreceptorsBaroreceptorsGlossopharyngeal (IX) and vagus (X) nervesM NUCHMedullaExcitationGlutamate secretionNucleus of tractus solitarius (NTS)ExcitationCaudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM)Inhibition↓GABARostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM)Reduced sympathetic outflowOMARROW

questions.question: Baroreceptor provides
questions.explanation: Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excitesthe vagal innervation of the heart.548Baroreceptor reflex• Increased BP → stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS → inhibition of RVLM →inhibition of sympathetic system•Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasympathetic stimulation• Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BPNTS Nucleus tractus solitarius-CVC Cardiovagal center-RVLM-Rostral ventrolateral medullaHR- Heart rateBP Blood pressure-

questions.question: Afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control goes to?
questions.explanation: Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS).Increased BP stimulates the baroreceptors which provide negative feedback in response to theincrease in blood pressure.Baroreceptor reflex:.• Increased BP → stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS →excitation of CVLM →inhibition of RVLM → inhibition of sympathetic system• Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasympathetic stimulation• Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BPNTS Nucleus tractus solitariusCVC Cardiovagal centre-CVLM Caudal ventrolateral medulla-RVLM Rostral ventrolateral medulla-HR Heart rate-BP Blood pressure-

questions.question: The low pressure receptors are

options.B: Stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

questions.explanation: The low-pressure receptors are stimulated by atrial systole and diastoleThe low-pressure receptors are those in the great veins, right and left atria and pulmonary vessels.Atrial stretch receptors are of two types:• Type A: discharge primarily during atrial systole• Type B: discharge primarily during late diastole549Distension of the atrial walls→stimulation of atrial receptors → Vasodilation, fall in BP andincreased heart rate.

questions.question: Occlusion of common carotid arteries on both sides leads to

options.A: Increase in heart rate and BP
options.B: Increase in BP and decrease in heart rate
options.C: Decrease in heart rate and BP
options.D: No effect on heart rate and BP540

questions.explanation: Occlusion of both common carotid arteries causes an increase in HR and BP.Reduced sinus pressure → response carried to nucleus tractus solitarius via glossopharyngeal andvagus nerve → less inhibitory effect on the vasomotor center.This leads to:• Decreased parasympathetic activity to the heart - Increases heart rate• Increased sympathetic activity to the heart and blood vessels - Increases heart rate, contractility,constricts arterioles - Increases TPR, constricts veins - increases venous returnNote: The carotid baroreceptors are located in the walls of the carotid sinus, which is located at orslightly above the bifurcation of the common carotid arteries. So, the occlusion of common carotidarteries is occlusion proximal to the carotid sinus.If the occlusion is distal to the carotid sinus increase in sinus pressure activation ofbaroreceptor reflex decrease in BP and HR.

questions.question: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is
questions.explanation: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is Angiotensin II.Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance anddecreases Na+ and H2O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.

questions.question: Marey's law states that

options.A: Heart rate varies directly with blood pressure
options.B: Heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure
options.C: Heart rate do not have any relation with blood pressure
options.D: Heart rate is directly proportional to cardiac output

questions.explanation: Marey's law states that the heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation?
questions.explanation: Increased venous capacitance is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation.Important effects of increased sympathetic stimulation:•• Arteriolar vasoconstriction• Increased stroke volume• Increased heart rate• Venoconstriction and decrease in venous capacitance550• The increase in mean systemic filling pressure is caused mainly by venous contraction.All these effects together bring about an increased arterial pressure.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding nitric oxide?
questions.explanation: Nitric oxide acts by increasing cGMP not by increasing cAMP.Nitric Oxide•Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF).• Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase(NOS).•Mechanism of action:NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → relaxation of vascular smooth muscle →vasodilation.• Effects of NO:• Vasodilation.•Neuromodulator in brain.●• Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells.• In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle.•• Penile erection.

questions.question: 541All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except
questions.explanation: Endothelin-1• Potent vasoconstrictor agent.• Produced by endothelial cells.•They are secreted locally and act in a paracrine fashion.Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)• Potent vasoconstrictor.• Platelet activation.•• Inotropic effect.• Closure of ductus arteriosus.• Have a role in the pathogenesis of hypertension, myocardial infarction, and congestive heartfailure..• In the brain, regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).• In the kidneys, they are involved in tubuloglomerular feedback→ ↓ GFR.551• In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors).• In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads toHirschsprung's/megacolon).•Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene→craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction.He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain anerection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the followingvasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.explanation: The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient.Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specificphosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging theaction of NO.Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation andengorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.question: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.explanation: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex.The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferentsignals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmittedback through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heartcontraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, andpulmonary circulation.Other options:Option A: Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in thecardiopulmonary region causes profound bradycardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoeafollowed by rapid shallow breathing.Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply toRostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia andhypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension,bradycardia, and irregular respiration.Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillaryreceptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and suffered a head injury. Onexamination, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible forelevated blood pressure in this condition?
questions.explanation: The reflex responsible for elevated blood pressure(BP) in head injury patients isthe Cushing reflex.552When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons iscompromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the centralchemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restorethe blood flow to the medulla.Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:• Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)• Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)• Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

questions.question: All of the following are rapidly acting blood pressure control mechanisms except:
questions.explanation: Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is not a rapidly acting pressure control mechanism,it is an intermediate-acting mechanism.Regulation of Arterial Blood Pressure:• Rapidly acting pressure control mechanism (acting within sec or min)• The chemoreceptor reflex.••The central nervous system ischemic mechanism.The baroreceptor reflex.• Intermediate-acting mechanisms (act after minutes).The capillary fluid shift mechanism.• Stress-relaxation of the vasculature.• The renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism.• Long-term mechanisms (after days)• Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)Note:• Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is an intermediate-acting mechanism, but waterconservation by RAAS is a long-term mechanism in the regulation of BP.•Most rapidly acting: Baroreceptor reflex>>Chemoreceptor reflex

questions.question: Which of the following neurotransmitters is correctly matched with an autonomic pathway?

options.A: Glutamate is released by Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla (CVLM) neurons projecting to theintermediolateral nucleus (IML)
options.B: GABA is released by Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) neurons projecting to the nucleusambiguus
options.C: GABA is released by CVLM neurons projecting to the Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla (RVLM)
options.D: Glutamate is released by CVLM neurons projecting to the NTS

questions.explanation: Basic Neural Pathway involved in Regulation of BP553Neural Pathway involved in regulation of BPBaroreceptorsIMLCN IX and XPreganglionicsympatheticneuronsAchMedullaGlutamateNTSRPostganglionicsympatheticAdrenalmedullaneuron (NE)GlutamateGlutamateCVLMGABARVLM(VMC)CVC (CIC)Nucleus ambiguusHeart andvasculatureOMARROW• NTS: Nucleus Tractus Solitarius• CVLM: Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla••• RVLM (VMC): Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla (Vasomotor center)• CVC (CIC): Cardiovagal center (Cardioinhibitory centerintermediolateral nucleus (IML)

questions.question: Stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors causes:
questions.explanation: Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies can produce variable effects on heartrate-•• Direct Effectvagal stimulation → bradycardia• Indirect effect• Hypoxia →peripheral chemoreceptor stimulation→ hyperventilation and increasedcatecholamine secretion → tachycardia and increased cardiac outputChemoreceptor reflex.• Receptors• Peripheral chemoreceptors in carotid and aortic bodies• Central chemoreceptors in the medulla• Stimulus• decrease in- PaO2• increase in-Pa CO2, H+ ion conc• Afferent554•IX (sinus nerve of Hering) and X (vagus N)• Center for reflex• Medulla• Efferent• Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart vasculature and adrenal medulla• Response• Direct effect- bradycardia• Indirect effect- hyperventilation, tachycardia, vasoconstriction, increased cardiac output andincreased BP

questions.question: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
questions.explanation: Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex.Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles,atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia,hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is calledBezold-Jarisch reflex.Other substances that can cause Bezold-Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, andveratridine.

questions.question: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture fromsupine to standing?

options.B: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase

questions.explanation: There is a decreased firing from the baroreceptors.• When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs,due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output.•Reduced cardiac output, leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firingfrom baroreceptors.• As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed leading to increased heart rate.555
